title: The Origin Story of KALIKA Reusable Beeswax Food Wraps
author: Seetha Govindaraju
body:
[[foodwaste.jpg]]

Jakarta Globe on food waste in Indonesia


If you type “food waste” into Google’s search engine, it will not even take two upward strokes of your fingers before you find where Indonesia ranks in the world as a contributor. That’s 300 kilograms of food waste per person and you can bet that more than half of that is organic. This is deeply saddening (and not to mention ironic) in a country where 8% of its whopping 4th largest global population still suffers from chronic hunger. 


[[plasticwaste.jpg]]

National Geographic on plastic affecting the ocean


If you are wondering which countries produce the most plastic waste that ends up down the orifices of sea turtles, yes, Indonesia will be found on top three of top three of that list too. Smack in the middle of ‘The Coral Triangle’ boasting the world’s highest diversity of coral reef fish, it is hard to digest that every single day, citizens of the nation are unknowingly contributing to the immense suffering of countless marine life. 


[[containers.jpg]]

Straits Times on Malaysian sending back 42 containers of illegally imported plastic waste to the UK


The fact that they import massive amounts of trash in containers from neighbouring countries doesn’t help. Suffice it to say, this creates a two-fold problem of food waste and a grossly incompetent plastic management system that insults food production efforts and the environment that allows us to do so. 


So much waste, so little action?


If you think that Indonesians just don’t care as long the wedding parties are overflowing with food and bananas are individually wrapped in cling film, then you are wrong! Multiple NGOs have made great strides in attempting to achieve zero hunger with leftover food before it becomes waste. Bali’s monumental move in being the first province to ban the use of single use plastic proves that the public are fed up with the damage that has been, and is being done.


[[ninaandreky.jpg]]

Say hello to Nina and Reky!

Meet KALIKA’s founders.


It is within the parameters outlining the food waste and plastic crisis that KALIKA came to life. Founders Nina Widjaja and Reky Martha, who had recently returned to their homeland in 2016, were dumbfounded by the reckless manner in which waste collects, be it on land or underwater. Their individual lifestyle changes in response to the environmental calamity inadvertently turned into an enterprise that could help fellow Indonesians make those changes too. 


[[IMG_3214.jpg]]

What exactly is a KALIKA? 


Starting out as a home DIY project to ease their pain in seeing so much plastic waste around them, reusable beeswax food wraps became their first solution to empower everyday folk to do the same. Sustainability and environmental consciousness are more than just personal philosophies, but also the building blocks of the business.


KALIKA works with local communities in responsibly harvesting wild forest beeswax. As it turns out, ancient human civilizations have been using beeswax to preserve their food rotting and it is high time we bring this tradition back!  


Think about the chain of benefits that come when you start wrapping your food with a KALIKA. You keep the food fresh longer. You keep money in your pocket because you are actually getting the most out of the food you buy. You keep quality food out of countless heaps of landfills. You keep unnecessary plastic waste out of the oceans because these wraps are 100% reusable. We could go on, or you could learn more why we make the best beeswax food wraps here.


[[IMG_3221.jpg]]

So, to wrap up...


KALIKA is here to offer you not just resources, but also lessons in learning how to keep your food as fresh as long as possible, which helps reduce food waste and single-use plastics as a brilliantly beneficial by-product. That being said, are you ready to give your food a second life?

title: How Reusable Beeswax Food Wraps can Reduce Food Waste and Plastic Pollution
author: Seetha Govindaraju
body:
[[plasticinocean.jpg]]

Rethink plastic waste is an initiative to save the oceans.


Doesn’t it sometimes seem like we have forgotten that we are humans living on planet Earth? That’s about as fundamental as it gets when it comes to explaining our existence. Yet, many of our actions have caused so much harm to our planet, that aliens observing us from far away must be baffled and asking themselves; “Why are these people destroying their home?”.


The environment is in peril. 

[[greta.jpg]]

Greta Thunberg sparked a worldwide movement with her "school strike for climate change" outside the Swedish parliament.


In more recent times however, the movement raging towards trying to mitigate the climate crisis has certainly prompted change. More and more individuals are starting to ask themselves “what can I do?”. Not all of us can skip school and strike outside the parliament, right? There are so many problems to tackle, but where to begin?


Keep things simple and just start from home. Experiment to find the right recipe on what works best for you. Start by establishing your own food waste and plastic management systems. Take a look inside your fridge. Do you see any dried out fruit, moldy cheese and rock-solid bread? Now just walk around your home. Do you see any plastic haphazardly lying around?   


Give your food a second life by learning how to actually keep it fresh.

[[foodlossvswaste.png]]

What's the difference between food waste and food loss?


Food waste is third on the list created by Project Drawdown, a fantastically put together organization that tackles the climate conundrum with gusto. First, understand that food loss and food waste are two different things. Second, ask yourself whether you are contributing to food waste, why this is happening, and what you can do to remedy it.  


Have you ever wondered why even when you wrap your food in cling film, it ends up soggy (or more or less dead-looking) before you come back to turn it into a smoothie? It’s because plastic suffocates your food. Even human skin has itty bitty pores that allow sweat to seep through so we can cool down when it gets too hot. Food has a similar mechanism. It needs to breathe too!


We definitely do not know how to manage all this plastic waste.

[[plasticlifecycle.jpg]]

Plastic Pollution Life Cycle


Look, there is nothing essentially wrong with plastic in itself. We are just extremely incompetent in figuring out what to do with it once we don’t need it anymore. What we throw in a bin, ends up in a landfill, then into the ocean which gets eaten by the fish and ultimately eaten by us. So in a nutshell, our mismanagement of plastic is invariably leading to us eating… trash!  


How KALIKA will help you live minimal waste.


Food banks are a great way to avoid food waste. But what about simpler individual actions one can take? We have cleared that wrapping your food in plastic does not really work and we know that beeswax contains antibacterial properties that prevent your food from becoming a home for microorganisms in a way cling film and plastic containers could only ever dream of.


[[IMG_2961.jpg]]

Reusable food packaging means you can say “NO!” to anyone who offers you a plastic bag to put your spinach in. It means you can go about your day knowing your artisan bread will stay nice and moist for an extra day or two. It means your food does not need to be subjected to an early second death because you are busy with everyday life. 


Critics will argue that beeswax food wraps are too expensive and that sustainable living should not cater only to the wealthy. To them we say, look up the word investment. KALIKA sells the most affordable beeswax food wraps in the world. After it has served you for over a year, you can toss it in your compost pile without the guilt of choking turtles swimming in your nightmares.


So, to wrap up…

[[IMG_2773.jpg]]


KALIKA offers a simple and cost-effective solution in dealing with the immense food waste and plastic pollution that us, humans, are producing. Despite our lifespans being barely a blink in the bigger picture of life, our actions today are what determine the fate of our home planet tomorrow. While activists and NGOs power on the pass policies preserving the planet, what can you do today, right from home, that will help planet Earth tomorrow?

title: 7 Reasons Why KALIKA makes the Best Reusable Beeswax Food Wraps
author: Seetha Govindaraju
body:
By now, you must already bee familiar with the program, right? We, at KALIKA, help empower everyday folk to reduce personal food waste and plastic consumption by using our reusable beeswax food wraps. With the plethora of options now made available to order and arrive at your doorstep, why should you choose KALIKA over ALL the others? Let us help you decide. 


We know that using the word “best” can be provocative but look, “best” is something better than the rest. Deciding what is best obviously needs to be analysed across all possible parameters, which is just what we have done in this article! 


1. We use wild forest beeswax to make our food wraps.


Do you know what beeswax is? Do you know how honey is made? The entire process is so long and complicated, yet structured and organized, that instead of running helter-skelter when a bee buzzes your way, you will applaud that highly competent winged productivity capsule. 


Essentially, beeswax is a by-product of bees’ honey-making process. Commercial acquisition of beeswax from bee farmers typically poses risks for bee welfare as humans tend to harvest all the honey. This increases the need to feed bees sugar water which, in excess, could lower overall bee productivity as they start storing sugar water in the hive in place of honey!


The good thing is that the bees get to live freely and since only the mature part of their nest is harvested, they do not have to start entirely from scratch. The downside is that this is a bit of a hazard for the forest bee farmers who have to climb massive trees, but safety is always an utmost priority and there have been no casualties thus far. 


∴ KALIKA gets beeswax from happy bees.


2. We are fair-trade.


When you harvest honey, you harvest the beeswax too. Unfortunately, most forest bee farmers do not know the true value of beeswax and simply dispose of it because it adds cost when you have to transport all that excess weight. 


KALIKA works with organizations that help educate forest bee farmers on the importance of using nature’s by-products to its full potential. This way, we know we get our beeswax in a responsible manner, and the forest bee farmers get to make additional profits from selling some gunk they would otherwise just throw away. Don’t we all just love these win-win scenarios? 


3. We get our fabric from working with local artisans.


[[Image1.jpg]]

For special edition beeswax food wraps, KALIKA works with local artisans to make batik prints that are hand stamped using 100% natural dyes. Some of these prints honestly look like they belong in a museum! So go ahead and wrap your lemon in a work of art. 


[[Image2.jpg]]

Browse our shop and compare it to the typical “beehive”/ “logo” motives of other beeswax food wrap merchants, and it will be near impossible to resist. Don’t lie, you know you want to wrap a handful of cashew nuts in that pink polka-dotted one. Our prints are candy for your eyes! 


4. We produce in-house with a diverse team.


KALIKA empowers an incredibly diverse team of people (young, old, men, women, you name it!) from various walks of life to commune daily in a small workshop to produce high-quality beeswax food wraps. Tender (and gloved) hands have crafted with the finest attention to detail, to perfect every single KALIKA. No big machinery, just manual labour and love.  


5. We ensure our products are affordable.


This time, browse the other sellers of beeswax food wraps and look at how much wanting to live more sustainably will cost you. KALIKA ensures that everyone can be a part of the solution by ensuring that our products are kept affordable. Costing you at least 40% less than the market average, it’s an investment, bargain and a great deal every single time. 


The stubborn adversaries should also stop fixating on how much money one spends on the wrap, instead on how much money one saves from throwing food in the bin. These beeswax food wraps are also re-u-sa-ble! We guarantee that if you actually did the math of calculating the cost of not using the wrap versus using it, you will regret not owning a KALIKA much sooner. 


6. We have a recipe that works wonders.

[[Image3.jpg]]

Our recipe which combines wild forest beeswax, tree resin and coconut oil, was a laborious undertaking of over 6 months worth of trial and error before we found one that… sticks!


[[Image4.jpg]]

Naturally, multiple home experiments, countless gooey accidents and competitor analysis are all part and parcel of the process. Yet, we eventually found a recipe that keeps the beeswax food wrap tight and taut around whatever it is you are trying to keep fresh longer.   


7. We try to be waste-free.


The best part about small companies, is that you can control virtually every single thing that goes on in it. Our aim, for both business and production, has always been to create a simple 2-in-1 solution on how to reduce food waste and plastic pollution. 


With in-house production powered by a team of skilled and dedicated worker bees, we make sure that almost nothing goes to waste. Even the fabrics are pre-measured before ordering and are trimmed with such precision, that loose threads littering the floor like cat hair is all the waste we ever see. 


Where most companies struggle to practice zero-waste as their commercial ambitions often far override sustainable practices, we are proud to say that we make every possible effort to be waste free. 


So, to wrap up…


Are you convinced yet? Or is there a parameter we are missing out? Let us know in the comments what you think, or rather, which KALIKA you decided to buy!

title: 10 Easy Ways to Reduce Food Waste From Home
author: Seetha Govindaraju
body:
Here at KALIKA, we are very passionate about food. Specifically, about ensuring that we fully appreciate the time and energy it takes to produce food. It is this philosophy that forms the backbone of our business. Sure, the perks of producing less plastic waste is great, but the real motivating force is as simple as our love for fresh, unprocessed food.


Of the 1.6 billion tonnes of food being wasted globally, 1.3 billion tonnes could have been eaten! So why are we throwing out so much perfectly good food? With living standards improving in more developed parts of the world, food is becoming more and more dispensable. However, we can reverse the economic and environmental consequences of food waste by acting from home.


That’s why in this article, KALIKA is here to show our appreciation for fresh food by sharing 10 simple and easily applicable tips on how to reduce food waste, from your very own kitchen! 


[[shoppinglist.jpg]]

#1 Shopping lists 

Before you go grocery shopping, always make sure you sweep your kitchen, refrigerator and pantry to make sure you do not double buy. Only then make your shopping list. Avoid bulk buying because what’s the point purchasing a giant bag of garlic if it ends up in the bin a week later forgotten? Pro-tip: Don’t grocery shop when you’re hungry! 


[[IMG_2645.jpg]]

#2 Self-serve food 

We are all victims of our disoriented hunger that makes us eat with our eyes sometimes. At house parties, let everyone serve themselves and have only small sized plates. Learn to be intuitive and stop eating when you feel satisfied, instead of getting used to finishing the giant portion sizes restaurants serve. It’s better to top up than toss out!


[[compost.jpg]]

A beginner's guide to composting

#3 Compost as second-to-last resort 

Composting is NOT the environmentally accepted way to throw your food out. According to the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, it's almost the least preferred way to deal with food waste as there are many steps preceding that. So, before you toss your unfinished caesar salad into the compost pile, learn how to do so properly. 


[[IMG_3260.jpg]]

#4 Declutter your refrigerator  

Your fridge is not a storage unit. It takes a lot of energy to keep food cold and you want to be sure you are using that energy efficiently. Declutter during your Sunday cleaning routine because out of sight, out of mind, right? Try the First In, First Out (FIFO) method and use the older items first moving them to the front so they are more visible to you. 


[[bestbefore.jpg]]

Out of date: the role of shelf life markings in food waste

#5 Expiry dates: Myth or Fact?

Confusion surrounding the “use by”, “best by” and other ambiguous dates on food labels cause billions of dollars worth of food waste. As a general rule, the “use by” date refers to food safety and the “best by” date refers to quality. It will take time before consumer education and standardized regulations to beef up. Meanwhile, try using common sense to tell whether or not something has really gone bad before throwing it out, please.  


[[IMG_2931.jpg]]

#6 Save leftovers 

Overestimated how much food you need or stood up by some friends at your dinner party? Just store the food in some glass containers and pack yourself a lunch. Label the food with the date so you know exactly how long it’s been in the fridge. Or cover your bowl with a KALIKA once it’s cool. 


[[wiltedgreens.jpg]]

Don't you dare throw out that wilty lettuce

#7 Bin into the blender and get creative

Perk up your wilted greens in cold water and toss them in the blender with fruit peel, pulp and whatever else looks juice-able to make a nutritious and fiber-ful leftover green juice! Some recipes lust for food nearing its death day. Bread pudding, fried rice and paella are ideas on how to salvage the bread, rice and random vegetables you have lying around.


[[IMG_3265.jpg]]

# 8 Infused water for the dehydrated soul

If you are one of those people who “don’t like the taste of water”, then jazz it up with some citrus peel whose zest still packs a punch of flavour. Bonus points if you have carbonated water for an especially refreshing and fizzy replacement to “just water”.


[[freezing.jpg]]

7 Vegetables that freeze well

#9 Befriend your freezer

Did you know that humans have been freezing food to last longer before there were even freezers? Fruits, vegetables, meat, fish, wine, nuts, herbs etc. Be it cooked or uncooked, you could reduce your food waste from home simply by using your kitchen appliances properly. Check out this ultimate guide before tossing everything in the cold!


[[IMG_2880.jpg]]

#10 Reorient your toss reflexes 

The problem is that we have gotten too used to food waste so it’s high time we orient our toss reflexes. Before you throw something out, get in the habit of asking yourself: Is there nothing I can do with this precious produce? Could you juice it, make a leftover recipe, freeze it, turn it into stock? If the answer is no, proceed to your compost pile. 


So, to wrap up…

Practice treating every stick of vegetable and slice of bread as though it costs $100. That way, you will want to be as resourceful as is humanly possible. If you succeed in finding a use for it tomorrow, don’t forget to wrap it in a KALIKA Beeswax Food Wrap to make sure it stays fresh!

title: Why Rebuild a Healthy Relationship With Food?
author: Seetha Govindaraju
body:
KALIKA started out as an effort to be sustainable and waste free. We also wish to encourage the feeling of gratitude for the food we are blessed to have. In this article, we want to talk about why we should invest in rebuilding a healthy relationship with food. 


[[unhealthy.jpg]]


An “unhealthy relationship with food” Google search yields eating disorders, hormonal diseases and mental illnesses. Typically, it has to do with our eating habits. However, the phrase fails to address the new kind of relationship we are forging with food now, the one causing food waste. 


What is a healthy relationship with food? 


[[IMG_2905.jpg]]


We eat multiple times, everyday, from the moment we are born till the moment we die. Food fuels our every activity. Food nourishes our body and mind. Food is absolutely essential to our survival. But do you know what it actually takes to get your food from zero to edible deliciousness on your plate? A whole lot! That’s why this food waste problem is so puzzling.  


While improper and excessive consumption can cause diseases to our bodies, less mindful food purchasing is causing damage to our planet and economy. The astonishing amount of food waste we produce points to another kind of unhealthy relationship with food. One that stems from consumerism and our ever-growing addiction to convenience. 


It seems we have almost forgotten the joy of saving, wrapping and storing precious food for later consumption, or why it’s even important to do so.


Easy come, easy go


Food delivery apps and supermarkets propping up around corners like mushrooms have made it easier than ever to own food and you need to own food to be able to waste food. The irony of food waste is that it could easily feed people who are actually hungry, four times over. Can you believe nearly half of the world population live in poverty? That’s more than 3 billion people!  


[[foodwaste.jpg]]


Promotions at the supermarket and consumer behaviour doesn’t help with this, like shopping whilst hungry with our eyes, or bulk buying discounted dairy products. Are we saving money if these foods end up moldy in the refrigerator? Ultimately, food wastage does not only affect the environment, but our health and in the long run, the economy too.   


[[foodproduction.jpg]]


Any food going uneaten or spoiled is a tremendous waste of resources spent planting, watering, nourishing, picking, cleaning, packaging, boxing, delivering, buying and chilling in the fridge. When you mindlessly toss food out, you are wasting a lot more than just food. The food in the landfill rots, releases methane, a greenhouse gas, which contributes to global warming. 


So, to wrap up...


[[IMG_2801.jpg]]


KALIKA is more than just a brand of beeswax food wrap, but also a movement towards mitigating food waste. Assess your own behaviour towards food. Question how you can be more intentional with it. Be mindful of your food-habits, from buying to eating to storing it. Try to understand the labour that went behind it, not just that of the food delivery man’s! 


Starting with why we should rebuild a healthy relationship with food, we can learn how to build a healthy relationship with food, together.

title: Healthy Food that keeps the Immune System Strong
author: Seetha Govindaraju
body:
Is it cheesy to say that the COVID-19 pandemic has gone viral? Probably. As a consequence, the most searched web query now is how to boost the immune system. Yet, there is no miracle cure that can do that. Keep yourself safe by practicing the protocols enforced by your respective governments. If you want to keep your immune system strong the proper way, read on.


[[ayurveda.jpg]]

Ayurvedic herbs that will help boost your immune system


Ever heard of Ayurveda? Despite the strong association with yogis and wellness experts obsessed with energy and excrement (seriously!), don’t write it off as bohemian sorcery just yet. Ayurveda is an ancient healing science originating from India, where it is still widely practiced. It is a recognized branch of complementary medicine that promotes preventative measures.


“Balance is the natural order. Imbalance is disorder.”


Catchy, right? Without side-stepping the importance of Western medicine, KALIKA enjoys the teachings of traditional medicine because it is ever-enduring. “Balance” refers to the harmony between our physical, mental and emotional state. Ayurveda looks at health from a holistic and mindful perspective. It teaches us to be conscious and emphasises preventing disease by practising sustainable healthy lifestyle choices. 

What does Ayurveda have to do with the immune system?

Our daily choices impact our health and ultimately, our immune system. The interconnectedness of mind and body that Ayurveda presses on is even known in modern medicine. For example, we know that mental health can affect your immune system. You can catch the cold when it’s flu season, but also when you’re overworked, sleep deprived and poorly fed. A strong immune system requires a balance supplemented by healthy habits that are maintained well.

Healthy non-fruit & vegetable foods that keeps the immune system strong

Here at KALIKA, we often highlight the importance of fruits and vegetables in our diets. Today however, let’s incorporate the Ayurvedic principle of holism and focus on the other types of food that promote health. Ayurveda goes back thousands of years and even our ancestors knew that achieving the right balance in life (and on our plates) keeps the immune system strong. 

In lieu of the pandemic, it’s been a little harder to get access to fresh greens and fruits. This article contains five foods that should be essential to a healthy diet that can keep your immune system strong, and strengthen it over time. The healthy foods listed here are shelf-stable, so you can stock up without worrying about food waste. Let’s get started!


#1 Nuts

[[nuts.JPG]]

Nuts are a great source of fibre, protein and healthy fats. It’s important to include these fats in your diet as they help make hormones like estrogen and testosterone. They also slow down the absorption of sugar so you don’t get that sugar high when you chug that fruit smoothie. 


👉 Roast them and blend on high in your food processor to make creamy nut butter. This is much healthier than store-bought versions as it doesn’t contain any added sugars or oils. 

👉 Add different types of nuts into a bowl and swap out your popcorn for a healthy snack.

👉 If you like to bake, add some chopped nuts into breads, scones and muffins. 


#2 Seeds

[[seeds.JPG]]

Chia seeds and flaxseeds are a reservoir for omega-3 fatty acids. Omega-3 is an essential fatty acid we cannot produce and obtain from our diet. It helps make the membrane of our cells, which is important (imagine a house without walls)! Sunflower seeds are rich in vitamin E, which is an antioxidant and immune booster. Seeds are also great for improving heart health.


👉 Sprinkle it over your morning oats, cereal or muesli. 

👉 Soak overnight and blend it into your homemade hummus recipe.

👉 Chop up and toss into salad or nourish bowls. 


#3 Spices 

[[spices.jpg]]

Health Benefits of Indonesia's Herbs and Spices

The real reason humans have been using spices for thousands of years is not just because it tastes good. It also helps preserve the food because they contain antibacterial properties. Turmeric should be a staple in your household not just for it’s warming flavour and vibrant golden colour, but it is also an anti-inflammatory. Great for after leg day! 


👉 Festive tasting Sunday pancakes recipe: Add some cinnamon and nutmeg powder to the batter so it tastes like apple pie. 

👉 If you like comforting curries, turmeric pairs incredibly well with coconut milk.

👉 Try experimenting by adding a pinch into your morning coffee for a burst of flavour.  

#4 Legumes 

[[legumes.jpg]]

A quick and easy fix to improve your diet

Legumes, or “pulses” are one of the most surprisingly nutritious foods that have gained popularity along with veganism. Did you know that besides being an excellent fibre and protein source, legumes contain a host of vitamins and minerals too? They are low in fat and free of cholesterol. Bet you will never look at beans the same way again...


👉 Chili con carne for vegetarians? Try adding red kidney beans, white beans and black beans. 

👉 Mung bean soup is a comfort that can be enjoyed for breakfast, a snack or dessert. Needing much less time to soak or cook, this is a quick recipe needing no more than 1 hour to whip up. 

👉 Add pre-cooked lentils or chickpeas into salads for extra protein and fibre.


#5 Miso paste

[[miso.jpg]]

What is miso paste?

You didn’t think we would talk about immune-healthy food without bringing up probiotics right? Enter miso, a thick paste made from soybeans fermented with salt and a koji starter. Rich in protein, vitamins and minerals, it promotes the growth of healthy gut bacteria due to the fermentation process. Introduce yourself to the wondrous taste of umami with miso paste!


👉 Obviously, miso soup! Add some paste into boiling water with some leafy greens and tofu. 

👉 Miso can be turned into salad dressings, marinades, glazes, dips and stir-fry flavourings by combining it with simple household ingredients like vinegar, sesame oil, hot sauce, lime etc. 

👉 Ran out of tea? Dilute in a cup of boiling water and sip up some flavoursome comfort.


So, to wrap up…

Unfortunately, there is no such thing as a boosted immune system. Rather than shopping online for supplements and quick health fixes, try instead to construct a wholesome diet to meet all your needs. No antioxidant rich immune boosting smoothie can kick your flu overnight. But… if you drink that smoothie everyday, then maybe we’re onto something.

title: The Ultimate Mindful Eaters Guide to Processed Foods
author: Seetha Govindaraju
body:
You would think that humans are an expert on nutrition, considering we’ve been on Earth and eating for over 300,000 years! Yet as time and technology trots on, our expansive knowledge of the biology of ourselves and food simply confuses us when it concerns... what to eat tonight.


[[1.jpg]]

Whole vs. Ultra-Processed Foods


The internet is ablaze with opinions of physicians, nutritionists, wellness experts, “influencers” and a never-ending cohort debating the question of which is better; whole foods or processed foods? In this article, let’s simplify the jargon and misconceptions, find reliable facts and come to a clearer understanding on how to better our diets together. This is the ultimate mindful eaters guide to processed foods.   


Whole Foods are classified as Processed Foods!

Bet you didn’t see that coming... The most comprehensive guide to food classification is NOVA. It categorises based on how much it has been processed and what we intend to use it for. It does not count calories and nutrients, therefore allowing us to grasp the concept of food from production to plate.


[[2.jpg]]

Everything, and we mean everything, that you eat, has undergone some level of processing.


Raw, natural, organic... They're all misnomers. When you pick a lime from your garden and wash it, that’s processing. When you blanch broccoli, that’s processing. When you wrap your vegetables in a KALIKA to extend shelf life, that’s processing. But you don’t want to eat a dirty lime or raw broccoli, do you?


The Ultimate Guide to Processed Foods: The different levels of processing

In this article, we’d like to share our knowledge on how to distinguish the different levels of processing the foods we eat undergo. Here is a summary of NOVA’s classification. 


Group 1: Unprocessed or minimally processed

[[3.jpg]]


What? Parts of plants and animals you can eat. Even fungi!


How? Removing inedible parts, drying, crushing, grinding, filtering, roasting, boiling, pasteurisation, refrigeration, vacuum sealing and non-alcoholic fermentation. These don't involve adding substances to the food like oil, salt or sugar but aims to extend their shelf life. Although they rarely contain additives, some milk undergone pasteurisation might have added stabilisers.


Examples? Fresh, squeezed, frozen or dried fruits and vegetables, grains, legumes, fresh or dried mushrooms, meat, eggs, milk, unsweetened fruit or vegetable juices, flour from corn, wheat, oats or cassava, pasta, nuts, seeds, herbs, spices, plain yoghurt, tea, coffee and water.



Group 2: Processed culinary ingredients

[[oil.jpg]]


What? These are Group 1 converted into products used in food preparation, seasoning and cooking. It can be used in home-cooked dishes, soups, broths, breads, preserves, salads, drinks and desserts. They may contain preservatives to retain the original product's properties or to prevent bacterial growth.


How? Pressing, refining, grinding, milling and spray drying. They are often consumed together with Group 1.


Examples? Salt, sugar, honey, syrup, vegetable oils, butter, starches, vinegar.



Group 3: Processed Foods

[[5.jpg]]

12 canned food products that can be healthy


What? A love child of Group 1 and Group 2, Group 3 typically contains 2-3 ingredients. It is made to be more durable and taste better. They definitely contain additives to prevent spoilage. 


How? It uses a combination of preservation or cooking methods to make products that are canned, bottled, salted, sugared and treated. Canned beans are high in sodium, which can lead to increased blood pressure so be sure to rinse the beans thoroughly first, and season with more herbs and spices than salt. 


Examples? Canned beans, fish, fruits, vegetables, cured or smoked meat, cheese and freshly made bread. If you think of alcohol as food, then it’s Group 3.


Group 4: Ultra-processed food and drink products.

[[6.jpg]]

Eating junk food increases risk of depression, study says


What? It should be cause for concern that a legitimate food classification system calls this an "industrial formulation". Primarily aiming to make ready-to-eat and artificially delicious foods, hallmarks of this food group are attractive packaging, aggressive marketing and questionable health claims. It contains five or more ingredients such as oils, sugars, fats, salt, stabilisers, flavouring, colouring, preservatives etc.


How? Extrusion, moulding and pre-processing for frying. Not concepts Grandma would be familiar with… 


Examples? Carbonated drinks, sweet or savoury snacks, ice-cream, chocolate, candies, mass-produced breads, margarines, spreads, cookies, pastries, cakes, cake mixes, breakfast cereals, energy bars or drinks, instant sauces and gravy, dairy-containing drinks, cocoa drunks, meat extracts, infant formulas, health and slimming products, pre-made pies, pasta, pizza, meat nuggets, sticks, sausages, burgers, hot dogs, powdered soups, noodles, desserts. What a mouthful!

Overwhelmed? Don’t worry! Here are some easy-to-follow rules;

👍 If you can tell that it’s real food by looking at it, eat. 

👎 If it looks like it was grown in a chemistry lab, avoid.

👍 If it has a label with a few ingredients that you can pronounce, eat.

👎 If a celebrity on the package boasts magnanimous health benefits, avoid.﻿﻿﻿﻿﻿﻿


﻿﻿﻿﻿﻿﻿﻿﻿﻿Are Whole Foods Better than Ultra-Processed Foods?

Well… They are higher in nutrients, fibre, healthy fats and lower in salt, sugar, unhealthy fats. They are better for the environment as there is much less industrial energy spent on processing and packaging. They are better for the local economy if you shop at a farmer’s market. They promote eating more home-cooked meals which is healthier than eating out. What do you think?

Processed Food and Health


The Mediterranean diet, which comprises mostly whole foods, is the most recommended diet for optimal health. Our bodies are adapted to thriving on whole foods. Therefore, our gut health is more suited to eating whole foods, whatmore natural sources of probiotics are garlic and cocoa.

More than half of the diet of the American population is processed food


Processed and ultra-processed food are more calorie-dense as opposed to nutrient-dense. So, you tend to overeat to satisfy your nutrient quota, as a recent study found. It is agreed upon by NOVA, and the health promoting community to avoid this group of food as much as possible. 


But processed foods are not all bad if used responsibly! 


Say, if you’re trying to reduce your meat intake by switching to canned chickpeas. Or if you’re a compulsive snacker opting for a healthier snack rather than forcing yourself to kick the habit. Or if your dose of daily greens is a pre-made salad. Worry only if you’re always reheating meals that resemble Play-Doh more than real food.

Processed food is not the enemy here, but a lack of awareness of what happens to our food from its origin to our mouths. Rather than counting calories, obsessing over diet fads and our weight, let’s focus instead on creating a sustainable and wholesome diet instead. The Brazilian Dietary Guidelines follow a Golden Rule that we too can live by; 


“Always prefer natural or minimally processed foods and freshly made dishes and meals to ultra-processed products.”
